docs.lead_paragraph: Brain researchers have found that the thrill gamblers feel involves the release of the same chemicals whose workings go awry in patients with Parkinson's disease. Now a small study being published today reports a link between Parkinson's patients with gambling problems and their medication. A survey of 1,884 patients seen at the Muhammad Ali Parkinson Research Center in Phoenix turned up nine who said their gambling had caused financial hardship. All were taking high doses of medicines that block the workings of the brain chemical dopamine.
docs.abstract: Dr Mark Stacy, Muhammad Ali Parkinson Research Center (Phoenix) director, reports, in journal Neurology, link between prescriptions to control Parkinson's disease and proclivity for gambling; suggests doctors should warn patients about potential for drug-induced gambling; cartoon (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the growing numbers of medical experts who preach evidence-based medicine -- the discipline that insists on proof that time-honored medical practices and procedures are actually effective -- there is no more inviting target than the annual physical. Checkups for people with no medical complaint remain the single most common reason for visiting a doctor, according to surveys by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. In 2000, they accounted for about 64 million office visits, out of 823.5 million visits over all. At $120 to $150 per visit (and $2,000 or so for the gold-plated ''executive physical'' that many companies offer to top executives), that adds up to more than $7 billion a year.

headline.main: Annual Physical Checkup May Be an Empty Ritual

docs.abstract: Annual medical checkups remain most common reason people visit their doctor, despite series of reports beginning in 1989 that find little support for symptomless physicals; committee sponsored by federal Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality finds routine physicals can lead to false alarms and unnecessary, and sometimes risky, follow-up tests; doctors admit they continue to do annual physicals for variety of reasons, including routine familiarity and simply keeping their patients happy, but they themselves question tangible benefit in yearly ritual; annual checkup does help establish doctor-patient relationship, giving people sense of confidence they have someone to help if symptoms do arise; story of Dr John K Min exemplifies dilemma doctors face; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Terry Heaton will not find out for at least another year whether the pills she tried for hot flashes were just blanks or really black cohosh, the much ballyhooed Native American remedy for women's ailments. As a participant in a federally financed study at Columbia University who dutifully recorded the frequency and severity of her hot flashes over 12 months, Ms. Heaton, a 56-year-old retired airline employee, could see that her menopausal symptoms were diminishing. She was definitely sleeping better.

headline.main: Herbs for Hot Flashes: New Attention, Mixed Results

docs.abstract: Various studies exploring use of herbs, dietary supplements and diet modifications yield mixed results in helping with symptoms of menopause; data confuse already disillusioned female population, after string of negative studies on widely used hormone replacement therapy; black cohosh, native American remedy, appears frontrunner among herbal remedies with several studies underway and some six-month trials completed; Amy Allina, National Women's Health Network in Washington's policy and program director, warns women not to assume because product is natural that it is safe; other studies are being done on effects of red clover, soy, flax seed, macrobiotic diets and alternative therapies such as acupuncture and relaxation techniques, some of which show promise; primary symptom of menopause, hot flashes, remains mysterious to doctors and, surprisingly, placebos are effective in relieving them in 30% of trial cases; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: The doctor possessed a fancy medical pedigree to complement his box-office looks. We met for the first time in a darkened ultrasound room, where he was to rule out the repairable cardiac anomalies that commonly accompany the birth defect already wreaking havoc on our fetus and my health. Fresh from residency, the young cardiologist invited an older one into our cave. They whispered earnestly, their voices further muffled by a blaring television set. The novice cardiologist had turned on the set before scanning my oversized belly. His superior scurried out of the room before the young man blandly broke the bad news.

headline.main: Not Too Late For a Lesson In Sensitivity

docs.abstract: Cases article recognizes difficult and frequently mishandled task of giving patients bad news; relates story about negative prenatal diagnosis unsympathetically rendered by novice cardiologist; holds that relationship established between then mother-to-be and young doctor exemplifies need for medical staff to be more sensitive about way patients are told about imminent death (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Undergarments, pajamas or mattresses with alarms triggered by moisture are the most effective way of curing a child of bedwetting, according to an article published yesterday. The article in the journal Effective Health Care said a good first step was to try some of the simpler behavioral techniques, like using a chart with stars or stickers to keep track of a child's success, or waking the child to use the toilet at night. But it warned that studies had found that parents are rarely prepared before they begin for the amount of work involved.
docs.abstract: Review by Cochrane Collaboration on details and data regarding bedwetting finds behavioral techniques are good start for training, followed, if necessary, by medications or alarm devices; evidence, presented in journal Effective Health Care, suggests parents need to be more prepared for amount of work needed to resolve bedwetting problem; cartoon (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Clues to the cause of disease are sometimes found in odd places, but rarely as odd as in the dried skin of a 50-year-old museum specimen of a flying fox from Guam. An article released yesterday, also in the journal Neurology, described the analysis of the skin of a kind of bat called a flying fox as part of an effort to unravel a possible link between environmental toxins and certain kinds of late-in-life dementia.

headline.main: From Dried Bat Skin, a Toxic Clue

docs.abstract: Drs Paul Alan Cox and Sandra Anne Banack of California State University (Fullerton) and neurologist Dr Oliver Sacks publish findings in journal Neurology that link historically high incidence of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis-Parkinsonian Dementia Complex among Chamorro tribe of Guam and ritual ingestion of toxic-laden flying fox bat; decline in disease parallels bat population decline (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: At 57, Dr. David L. Heymann has had an extraordinary career. The epidemiologist has helped discover two new diseases (Ebola and Legionnaire's), rid the world of an old one (smallpox) and stop spread of the newest (SARS). Now the American physician is running a World Health Organization program that aims to eradicate polio by 2005. If successful, polio will join smallpox as the only naturally occurring diseases to be wiped out, and the United Nations agency will have erased the two.

headline.main: A Specialist in Fighting New Diseases Is Chosen to Wipe Out an Old One

docs.abstract: Epidemiologist Dr David L Heymann has been appointed director of World Health Organization program to eradicate polio by year 2005; well-known for his efforts during recent SARS epidemic, Heymann's career traced; his first assignment while working with Epidemic Intelligence Service program at Centers for Disease Contol and Prevention in Atlanta involved him in investigation of Legionnaire's Disease, then new illness, and within few weeks investigation of hemorrhagic fever that turned out to be Ebola Virus; World Health Organization Secretary General Dr Jong Wook Lee, who drafted Heymann for polio project, hails him as most important communicable disease control expert in world; hopes project will not only eradicate polio, but strengthen public health infrastructure and generate new ways of combating emerging disease; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Many women of childbearing age who develop breast cancer worry that the stresses and hormonal changes of pregnancy will be dangerous. But a new study released yesterday in the journal Cancer found that becoming pregnant after a diagnosis does not raise the risk of dying. The study, led by Dr. Beth A. Mueller of the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle, said the issue was particularly pertinent because the number of women younger than 45 in whom breast cancer is discovered is increasing.
docs.abstract: Dr Beth A Mueller, Seattle's Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center doctor, leads study published in journal Cancer that shows becoming pregnant after breast cancer does not increase risk of dying, but rather increases chance of survival (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: There's nothing nicer than a tune playing in your head -- until you can't turn it off. The phenomenon has spanned the ages. In 1882, Mark Twain wrote in a short story of an annoying ''jingling rhyme'' that became indelibly lodged in the author's mind until he passed the curse along to another hapless victim. This summer, a community board in Brooklyn has called for a limit on the playing of the ''Mr. Softee'' jingle by ice-cream trucks -- a jingle that can be unbearably memorable for those subjected to it for extended periods.

headline.main: When the Brain Grabs a Tune and Won't Let Go

docs.abstract: Consumer psychologist Dr James Kellaris, studying phenomenon he calls earworms, or songs stuck in your head, determines 98% of listeners are bothered by tune that will not go away, with those having music training or compulsive tendencies being most affected; University of Cincinnati study, led by Kellaris, and involving 559 students, lists variety of songs that haunted listeners and gives basic advice on how to correct problem; songwriter Neil Diamond talks about positive side of earworms; photos (M)
